awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Deceptive Self-Signals - Activating Political Identity to Affirm a Positive Self-Image
awd_abstract_narration:
General

A large amount of political expression today occurs in social network settings.  These are low-stakes exercises in which individuals simply express opinions that are often anonymous, or essentially anonymous. This proposal seeks to explain why individuals express support for certain policies and political parties on social media when doing so is unlikely to enhance their social standing, material well-being, or to influence public policy. In particular, the PI asks whether individuals gain some type of benefit simply from making such expressions, even if they do so anonymously, and assesses whether the motivations underlying political expression are distinct from those of other types of expression.  While this type of political expression is extremely common, we lack clear answers to why people do it and what benefits they gain from it.  This study provides a new explanation for a type of political behavior based on a concept from the field of behavioral economics known as self-signaling. In this respect, the study helps to explain an emerging type of political behavior by utilizing an interdisciplinary approach.  By gaining a better understanding of the individuals' different motivations, the study has the potential to increase the likelihood for positive collective outcomes in an era marked by high degrees of political polarization.

Technical

In this project, the PI theorizes that people are motivated to make political expressions partly as a low-cost way of signaling to themselves that they possess certain desired attributes, values, and associated behavior.  Individuals have incomplete knowledge about extent to which they possess desired attributes and values, and use political expression as a low-cost way to gain a positive self-image.  Further, although both self-identified liberals and conservatives are similarly motivated to engage in this behavior, they do so to activate different desired self-images associated with their respective ideological disposition. Expressing support for liberal policies is a relatively costless way for self-identifying liberals to feel that they are generous and compassionate, just as expressing support for conservative policies is a low-cost way for self-identifying conservatives to feel moral and self-reliant. That said, people do not put their "money where their mouth is." Self-identified liberals do not donate more to charity, nor are self-identified conservatives more moral. Thus, political expression may constitute a form of deceptive self-signaling. To evaluate this theory, the PI utilizes an innovative experimental design. Specifically, the PI tests whether subjects exhibit an enhanced self-image following anonymous political expression, and whether the attributes on which subjects rate themselves more highly correspond with their ideology. Next, the PI tests whether individuals feel they can act more selfishly after engaging in political expression, especially when the costs to acting in a manner consistent with the desired values increases. Last, the PI investigates whether appealing to individuals-specific self-images can lead them to engage in political expressions that entail higher costs, which could lead to more desirable types of collective outcomes.

por.por_cntn:
What motivates individuals to engage in online political expression? Are the determinants of online political expression different from those underlying online non-political expression? These questions are not easily answered by extant literature on expressive motivations. In particular, four features of expression on social media pose a challenge to extant understandings. First, people are often anonymous or, where limited private information is provided and visible to strangers, effectively anonymous. Second, they are not acting out of material self-interest; to the contrary, they are spending time on an action that is very unlikely to produce any conceivable targeted material benefits. Third, individuals are usually not seeking to improve social welfare: online debates between strangers are not expected to lead to policy change, and much of the dialogue is not aimed at persuasion. Fourth, expression is often of low salience: comments often go unseen or do not garner any responses.

In this paper, I draw on theories of self-signaling to hypothesize that people are motivated to express themselves politically in such settings in part to cheaply secure a positive self-image. According to these theories, people have imperfect knowledge of their own values, attributes or true "type". For instance, how truly religious, tolerant, or disciplined one is can be difficult to self-diagnose. Individuals are as a result "chronically uncertain about where they stand with respect to these broad attributes, which in turn makes their choices diagnostic" (Prelec and Bodner 2003, 4). However, because people value a positive self-image, they do not seek to generate just any news about themselves, but positive news. To do so, they engage in behavior that is not causally related to their underlying characteristic of interest but which they nevertheless treat as diagnostic in the desired direction. Consistent with this set of theories, studies have found that people manipulate personality self-reports, problem solving strategies, and charitable pledges "in a diagnostically favorable direction" (Prelec and Bodner 2003, 6).

In the same vein, I hypothesize that individuals may engage in otherwise puzzling online political expression in order to generate favorable diagnostic self-signals of underlying characteristics about which they remain uncertain. Political expression becomes one avenue to obtaining an improved self-image because individuals have strong partisan identities that they associate with attributes: for instance, Democrats are stereotyped as more empathic and tolerant, and Republicans as more patriotic, tough, and hardworking. As I document in my pilot study, individuals who identify as Democrats and Republicans more highly value the traits or attributes associated with their preferred political identity. By activating their political identities, then, partisan identifiers cheaply affirm their possession of desired attributes associated with their political party.  

Finding a low-cost way to affirm a positive self-image is important insofar as actually behaving in a way that affirms one's desired attributes comes at a cost that people are unwilling to bear. Indeed, while Democrats and Republicans may wish to see themselves as particularly generous or tough, respectively, evidence suggests that such differences are more imagined than real. Put differently, there is evidence that individuals do not "put their money where their mouth is": experimental games show that Democrats do not behave more generously toward others when it is costly to do so, nor are Republicans always more discerning about who is deserving or not deserving of aid. Political expression provides a solution whereby individuals can feel positively about themselves without having to expend much effort for their enhanced self-image.

I conduct an online experiment to test my theory and find preliminary evidence of self-signaling. Specifically, individuals appear to use political expression as a means to increase self-perceived ownership of desired attributes that are associated with their political party. Effects are strongest for those who are prone to political expression in the first place, that is, those who report a high level of political engagement. While results appear to be supportive of my theory, more evidence with a larger sample and additional treatments is required. Accordingly, I intend to further evaluate my theory in future work. Future research may also focus on how signaling to unknown others can similarly enhance an individual's self-image. Finally, we may ask how to encourage welfare-improving or "good" political expression: that is, expression that enhances individuals' self-images without exacerbating inter-group animosities, or which translates into positive action.
